header.title: Jeremy Clarkson, my sexuality is not the butt of the joke
header.postText: The first time I remember hearing the word ‘gay’, I was walking through my primary school hallway. A student stopped me and said my Spice World t-shirt was ‘so gay’.', 'A bunch of other students turned and laughed at me. I was mortified. A wave of shame crashed over me. As soon as I got home from school, I took my t-shirt off and threw it in the bin.', 'It took me a very long time to work through the damage done to my mental health because of anti-LGBT bullying and language, and to get to a place where I could be proud of being gay. That’s why it’s so troubling to hear Jeremy Clarkson using archaic stereotypes about LGBT people as a joke, like he did in a recent episode of The Grand Tour.', 'Language is so important and the words we choose to use when describing or referring to someone’s identity has power. Belittling or mocking people who suffer daily discrimination because of who they are ignores the negative impact this can have on people from those communities.', 'It’s incredibly painful and hurtful for anyone to hear parts of their identity being treated as a gag or comic relief', 'We also know that homophobic, biphobic and transphobic language continues to be a real issue in Britain and in our schools. The majority of LGBT pupils (86 per cent) regularly hear phrases like ‘that’s so gay’ or ‘you’re so gay’ in school, while almost half (46 per cent) ‘frequently’ or ‘often’ hear transphobic language, such as ‘tranny’ or ‘he-she’.', 'So when this kind of language is dressed up as ‘banter’ or ‘jokes’ that people hear on television, it further perpetuates the idea that it is acceptable. It also reinforces a damaging narrative that being LGBT is inferior or something to be ridiculed.', 'Before I had even come to terms with being gay, I learnt, in that one quick incident, that ‘gay’ was something to be made fun of, and consequently, to be ashamed of.', 'Unfortunately, this would not be the last time I was the target of such homophobic taunting growing up – and neither is it the first time the The Grand Tour presenters have made homophobic remarks. Three years ago, Richard Hammond claimed he does not eat ice cream because he’s straight.', 'It’s incredibly painful and hurtful for anyone to hear parts of their identity being treated as a gag or comic relief. Being lesbian, gay, bi and/or trans should never be the punchline of anyone’s joke.', 'That’s why the way the media represents and talks about LGBT people is such a crucial part of making the world a more accepting place.', 'Jeremy Clarkson’s recent comments, and what Richard Hammond said three years ago, are just two examples that show much work is left to do to combat discrimination and the use of hateful language against lesbian, gay, bi and trans people.', 'Changing the way LGBT people are talked about on-screen can have a hugely positive impact on the way these conversations happen on school playgrounds and in the hallways.', 'If we’re going to change the way people think and feel about LGBT people, we need more shows with greater and more diverse representations of LGBT people from all walks of life.
